title: In the Drops: Stubble & Co’s Roll Top Backpack, ‘The Race of Truth’ by Leigh Timmis, OneOdio Open Rock S Earbuds and Annemiek van Vleuten’s retirement
content:
Cyclist
In the Drops: Stubble & Co’s Roll Top Backpack, ‘The Race of Truth’ by Leigh Timmis, OneOdio Open Rock S Earbuds and Annemiek van Vleuten’s retirement

Happy Friday! I’m back with another In the Drops, but first, let’s recap what’s been going on at Cyclist recently.

It’s a double-James special for the latest Cyclist Magazine Podcast episode, where deputy editor James talks to former-pro-turned-philosopher (a different path than gravel riding for ex riders) James Hibbard on his latest book and life’s scariest philosophical questions. Matthew has expounded on the delights of folding bikes while Paddy Madison discovered why the Hardknott Pass is the hardest climb in England.

The Tour of Britain is in full swing, with a dominating display so far by Olav Kooij, Wout van Aert and their Jumbo-Visma teammates. The Vuelta a España is also in its second week, with Sepp-tember looking pretty promising.

Related Posts

Stubble & Co’s The Roll Top Backpack

My sister is about to set off on the Yorkshire 3 Peaks challenge and as someone who spent last summer walking around the Peak District with her, the usefulness of a good backpack crammed with water bottles is not wasted on me. I’m still trying to fit in longer walks and hikes as the summer sun insists on staying out for just a while longer, and this backpack from Stubble & Co is extremely good.

Designed for cycling and the outdoors in general, the backpack is made lightweight and comes in either 14L or 20L sizes. There are two side pockets and water-resistant zips, although fortunately I haven’t needed to test its full capabilities against rain just yet. There are also compartments and pockets galore inside, ideal for cycling trip essentials, laptop carrying or general life bumf. It all closes with the roll top and G clip.

  • Buy now from Stubble & Co (£105)

The Race of Truth by Leigh Timmis

My Goodreads account is limited in its variety. I either pick up mystery/crime tales, cycling reads or psychological books with a nod towards experiencing a quarterlife crisis for those named Robyn, aged 25, living in Manchester. Anyway.

Leigh Timmis made history in 2018 by becoming the fastest person to ride across Europe. His time of 16 days, 10 hours and 45 minutes beat the previous record by 8 days and 17 hours. But, as he explains in this book, such an ultra-endurance world record challenge isn’t simply a case of being fast. He also had to mentally prepare. Timmis was diagnosed with depression – something relatable to myself – and attempted a series of sporting challenges afterwards, the titular ‘race of truth’ across Europe being one of them.

The Race of Truth an intimate read, one where Timmis not only takes us on his journey to the finish line in Portugal, but also exposes his vulnerabilities and determination for all to see. It’s truly something.

  • Buy now from Waterstones (£10.99)

OneOdio Open Rock Earbuds

The Open Rock S Earbuds from OneOdio are adjustable to suit the shape of your ears and can provide 46 hours of music and calls – handy for Cyclist Teams meetings and listening to Mac Miller on repeat throughout the day. In comparison to the previously mentioned OpenRock Pro earbuds from Matthew, the OpenRock S has a longer playing time of 60 hours with the charging case and an updated Bluetooth, all for a cheaper price.

Should you only have five minutes to quickly charge them, the earbuds still give 60 minutes of playing time, which suits someone (aka, me) who frequently forgets to charge theirs before heading out to the shops and can’t bear to be left alone with the sound of their own thoughts.

  • Buy now from OneOdio (£81)

What we’re into this week: The career of Annemiek van Vleuten

At the time of writing, Movistar’s Annemiek van Vleuten is currently participating in the final race of her professional career: the Simac Ladies Tour. I’m honestly devastated at her retirement. I grew up enthralled with this entertaining Dutchwoman on her bike, taking risks I could never dream of and collecting the biggest accolades in the sport.

You name it, she’s probably won it. La Vuelta Femenina. The Giro Rosa/Donne. The Tour de France Femmes. Tour of Flanders. Liège Bastogne-Liège. World Championship Road Race. World Championship Time Trial. European Championship Road Race. National Championship Time Trial. National Championship Road Race.

Van Vleuten has been present for such welcoming changes in the sport: race expansions, a growing peloton, increasing prize money… While this marks a changing-of-the-guard moment, I can’t help but feel a twinge of melancholy at the concept of a Van Vleuten-less peloton going onwards. But what a career. What an athlete. What a phenomenal person.
